Panel (s) shows the calculated adsorption energies and the amount of charge transferred between each single TM atom and C3N3 support. In the charge density difference plots, green and red isosurfaces represent regions of charge depletion and accumulation, respectively. The isosurface value is set to e/bohr3. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Spin-polarized projected density of states of (a, e, i) pristine C3N3, (b) Co/C3N3, (c) Ni/C3N3, (d) Cu/C3N3, (f) Zn/C3N3, (g) Ru/C3N3, (h) Pt/C3N3, (j) Au/C3N3, (k) Ag/C3N3, and (l) In/C3N3. The pink dotted line represents the Fermi level (EF). Single-atom catalysts (SACs) anchored on triazine-based 2D carbon nitride (C3N3) offer a promising pathway for efficient and selective electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. However, a clear understanding of the CO2 reduction process on C3N3-supported SACs is still lacking. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are employed to uncover a comprehensive mechanism and the origin of activity of various transition metal atoms (Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, In, Au, and Ag) on C3N3 monolayer. The importance of the adsorption mode is revealed, as key intermediates exhibit distinct binding configurations that significantly impact catalytic performance. Electron accumulation near the single metal sites activates CO2 via charge redistribution and π-backdonation mechanisms. Thermodynamic and kinetic analyses indicate that Co, Cu, and Ru favor CO formation due to optimal adsorption energies and moderate *CO binding, while Cu and In promote HCOOH production through stabilized *OCHO intermediates. Charge density differences, projected density of states (PDOS), and reaction free energy pathways highlight the role of d-orbital–intermediate coupling and active site characteristics in product selectivity. Additionally, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) analysis reveals that Co, Cu, Ru, and In exhibit higher ΔG_H* values, indicating suppressed HER activity and enhanced CO2RR selectivity compared with Pt and Ni. These insights provide a mechanistic foundation for the rational design of high-performance SACs supported on C3N3 for efficient CO2 conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single-Atom Catalysts (SACs) Carbon Nitride (C3N3) CO2RR DFT Product Selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In 21st century, climate change has emerged as one of the most pressing global challenges, primarily driven by excessive anthropogenic CO2 emissions resulting from the widespread use of fossil fuels as the dominant energy source [1,2]. These emissions contribute significantly to the intensification of the greenhouse effect, global warming, sea-level rise, and ecological degradation [3–5]. In response to these threats, there is an urgent need to develop sustainable and economically viable technologies for carbon dioxide capture and utilization [6]. To mitigate these environmental impacts and transition toward a low-carbon future, numerous technologies are being explored for the conversion and storage of renewable energy [7–10]. Ideal systems must be cost-effective, environmentally benign, and capable of delivering high energy densities to meet growing global demands [7,11,12]. CO2, being a low-cost and abundant carbon source, has gained attention as a feedstock for the production of value-added chemicals and fuels [13,14]. Its transformation into useful products provides a dual benefit: reducing atmospheric CO2 concentrations while offering alternative energy carriers or industrial precursors [15]. Commercially viable CO2 conversion technologies such as electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis, and hydrogenation are under intensive investigation for their potential to replace fossil-fuel-based production pathways [13,14,16–18]. This strategy not only addresses carbon emissions but also contributes to diversifying the energy portfolio with sustainable alternatives. Among these approaches, electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) has emerged as a promising route for the sustainable production of fuels and chemicals under ambient conditions [19]. This approach employs electrical energy preferably sourced from renewable resources to drive the electrochemical reduction of CO2 into value-added compounds, including carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), methane, ethylene, and various alcohols [14,20,21]. Among them, formic acid is particularly valuable due to its industrial applications and its role as a liquid hydrogen carrier [5,16]. It can be catalytically decomposed into CO2 and H2 at mild conditions, making it suitable for on-demand hydrogen release and clean fuel applications [8,22]. The CO2RR typically involves complex proton-coupled electron transfer steps occurring at the electrode–electrolyte interface. The reaction pathway and product distribution are highly sensitive to the catalyst structure, applied potential, and reaction environment [20]. The primary challenge lies in the activation of the chemically inert CO2 molecule, especially the cleavage of the C = O bond. This step requires significant overpotentials, typically around −1.49 V vs. RHE, and competes directly with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which occurs under similar electrochemical conditions and can suppress CO2RR selectivity [14]. To address these challenges, transition metal-based molecular and heterogeneous catalysts have been extensively studied. Metals such as Fe, Co, Ru, and Cu, coordinated with N-doping, can promote CO2 activation and stabilize reaction intermediates [23–25]. However, molecular catalysts often suffer from poor stability and recyclability under practical conditions. Heterogeneous catalysts, in contrast, offer improved durability and are more compatible with device integration. Recent efforts have focused on optimizing the catalytic interface to improve activity, selectivity, and stability. Strategies such as alloying, vacancy engineering, heterostructure formation, and support tuning have been explored. Among the advanced catalyst systems, single-atom catalysts (SACs) comprising isolated metal atoms dispersed on conductive supports have emerged as a frontier in field of catalysis [20,26–31]. These systems combine the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis by offering well-defined active sites with high metal utilization efficiency and tunable coordination environments [32]. Despite their potential, synthesizing stable and uniformly dispersed SACs remains challenging due to the high mobility and aggregation tendency of metal atoms [28,30,33]. Various fabrication methods have been developed, including atomic layer deposition, wet-chemical synthesis, and mass-selected soft landing [34,35]. Among these, the wet-chemical approach is particularly scalable but demands support materials that can strongly anchor individual atoms to prevent migration and sintering [35]. In single-atom catalysts (SACs) for CO2 reduction (CO2RR), the isolated transition metal (TM) atom acts as the active site for CO2 adsorption and activation, while the support facilitates charge transfer, modulates local electronic structure, and stabilizes key intermediates [9,14,16,24]. Transition metals with partially filled d-orbitals, such as Co, Ni, and Cu, are particularly effective due to their ability to engage in charge transfer with CO2, leading to distortion of its linear geometry and weakening of C = O bonds which is crucial steps in activation and reduction [16,36]. The selectivity of these metals toward products like CO or HCOOH is governed by their specific binding affinities to *COOH and *OCHO intermediates [5]. However, challenges remain in achieving uniform atomic dispersion at high loading, suppressing the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and understanding active site dynamics under operating conditions. To address these issues, strategies such as optimizing metal–support interactions, engineering vacancies or defects, and reducing metal loading have been explored. An ideal support should offer high surface area, strong anchoring sites, and short charge migration pathways to ensure stable dispersion, efficient electron transfer, and enhanced catalytic performance. Two-dimensional triazine-based carbon nitride (C3N3) has attracted growing attention due to its unique planar structure, high chemical stability, and metallic conductivity [37]. Unlike traditional semiconducting carbon nitrides, C₃N₃ exhibits a delocalized π-electron network that endows it with metallic character and zero bandgap, making it a promising support for electrocatalysis. Its extended conjugated structure and abundant nitrogen coordination sites provide multiple anchoring points for transition metal (TM) atoms, facilitating the design of efficient single-atom catalysts (SACs) for energy conversion applications [25,37,38]. In this study, we developed a C3N3 based single-atom catalyst model by anchoring single TM atoms (Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, In, Au, Ag) onto C3N3 monolayers. Using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we examined the stability of these TM atoms on C3N3, their binding energies with CO2, and the interaction energies of key CO2RR intermediates. Our analysis addressed three key questions: (i) Which TM atoms can be stably adsorbed on the C3N3 surface without aggregation? (ii) Which TM atoms show the most promising electronic characteristics for CO2 activation? (iii) How do the adsorbed TMs influence the CO2RR pathways and product selectivity? The results demonstrate that single TM atoms exhibit the most stable adsorption on C₃N₃, owing to favorable binding energies and strong metal support interactions. These single atoms effectively activate CO2 molecules by inducing geometric distortion and weakening the C = O bond through localized charge redistribution and π-backdonation. Product selectivity analysis reveals that Cu and In favor the formation of formic acid (HCOOH) by stabilizing *OCHO intermediates, while Co, Cu, and Ru promote CO evolution due to stronger *CO stabilization. These active sites also operate with minimal overpotentials, underscoring their thermodynamic efficiency. Overall, this work offers detailed mechanistic insights and valuable design principles for the rational development of high-performance, product-selective SACs supported on C3N3 for efficient CO2 electroreduction. 2 Computational setup The computational study was performed using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations, implemented through the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [39–41]. The exchange-correlation potentials were treated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [42]. The empirical correction in Grimme’s method (DFT+D3) was adopted to describe van der Waals interaction [43]. Structure relaxation was conducted using a 4 × 2 × 1 k-point grid and an energy cutoff of 450 eV. During optimization, ionic relaxation followed standard energy convergence criteria of 10–5 eV, with force convergence criteria set at −0.02 eV/Å. A 5 × 5 supercell model of carbon nitride (C3N3), consisting of 25 carbon and 25 nitrogen atoms, was constructed as a substrate for the single atom catalyst (SAC). To minimize interactions between periodic images, a separation of approximately 15 Å was maintained between neighboring cells. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI- NEB) method [44] was employed to calculate the migration barriers of the single atoms from a hole site to the nearest hole site on C3N3. Bader analysis was employed to examine charge population and charge transfer [45,46]. The adsorption energy (E ads) was calculated using the following equation: (1) E ads = E SAC / C 3 N 3 − E C 3 N 3 − E bulk metal / N Where E (SAC/C₃N₃) is the total energy of the single-atom catalyst adsorbed on the C3N3 surface, The E (C₃N₃) is the energy of the pristine C3N3 substrate, and E bulk metal/N represents the energy of a single metal atom derived from its bulk phase. A negative value of E ads indicates an exothermic adsorption process, implying that the single-atom structure is thermodynamically stable on C3N3. The gas-phase molecules H2, H2O, and CO2 were modeled in a box with dimensions of 27 Å × 27 Å × 20 Å to avoid intermolecular interactions between periodic images. Bader charge analysis was employed to investigate the charge redistribution and quantify charge transfer phenomena [46]. The electrochemical reduction pathways proceed via the formation of two-electron transfer intermediates, such as HCOO* and *COOH. These intermediates undergo further two-electron reduction steps, ultimately producing formic acid (HCOOH) or carbon monoxide (CO), respectively. The reaction steps involved in HCOOH production are described by Eqs. (2-4): (2) * + C O 2 ( g ) + 2 ( H + + e − ) → * O C O H + H + + e − (3) * O C O H + H + + e − → H C O O H * (4) HCOOH * → HCOO H ( g ) + * This sequence of reactions represents the pathway for formic acid (HCOOH) production, wherein CO₂ is first reduced to the surface-bound *OCOH intermediate, which undergoes a further proton–electron transfer step to form HCOOH. The reaction steps involved in CO production are described by Eqs. (5 - 7 ): (5) * + C O 2 ( g ) + 2 ( H + + e − ) → * C O O H + H + + e − (6) * C O O H + H + + e − → * C O + H 2 O ( l ) (7) * C O → C O ( g ) + * This series of reactions illustrates a two-electron reduction pathway, in which CO2 is initially converted to the surface-bound *COOH intermediate, followed by further reduction to *CO. In the final step, CO is desorbed from the catalyst surface and released into the system as a gas. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) proceeds via the following steps: (8) H + + e − + * → H * (9) H * → 1 ( H 2 ) 2 + * where '*' represents the active catalytic site and H* denotes the adsorbed hydrogen intermediate. Zero-point energy, entropy, and enthalpy corrections were applied to the adsorbed species to convert the calculated electronic energies into Gibbs free energies. The Gibbs free energy (G) at zero voltage is expressed by Eq. (10): (10) G = E DFT + E ZPE − TS + ∫ C p d T where EDFT is the electronic energy obtained from DFT calculations, EZPE is the zero-point energy, ∫CpdT accounts for the enthalpy correction, T is the temperature (typically 298.15 K), and S is the entropy of the system. The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model is employed to calculate the Gibbs free energy of reaction steps involving coupled proton–electron transfers. In this framework, the free energy of a proton–electron pair (H + + e −) is referenced to the chemical potential of half a hydrogen molecule and corrected for the applied potential relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), as given by: μ(H +) + μ(e −) = 1 2 μ(H2) – eU (vs RHE) [47]. Using this relation, the adsorption free energies of key intermediates such as H C O O * , H C O O H * , * C O O H , and * C O at a given potential U R H E can be calculated as: (11) Δ G 1 ( * O C O H ) = G ( * O C O H ) − G ( * ) − G ( C O 2 ( g ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (12) Δ G 2 ( H C O O H * ) = ( H C O O H * ) − ( * O C O H ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (13) Δ G 3 ( * C O O H ) = G ( * C O O H ) − G ( * ) − G ( C O 2 ( g ) ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (14) Δ G 4 ( * C O ) = G ( * C O ) − G ( * C O O H ) + G ( H 2 O ( 1 ) ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electronic structure and stability of transition metals supported on C3N3 Durability and practical applicability are fundamental criteria for evaluating catalyst performance, particularly for electrode materials, even from a theoretical standpoint. Accordingly, we first analyze the structural properties of C3N3 monolayer with single TM catalyst (SAC) adsorption, as depicted in (Fig. 1 ). To anchor SACs, we constructed a periodic 5 × 5 supercell of a C3N3 monolayer containing C = 25 and N = 25 atoms (Fig. 1a). The scanning tunneling microscope (STM) simulation presented in Figure S1 revealed that the 5 × 5 supercell of C3N3 is composed of C = 25 and N = 25 atoms. Furthermore, we have adsorbed SAC on different site of C3N3 and find that hole site where SAC connected with C and N atoms (Fig. 1 b, Figure S2) are the most active site for SACs adsorption. Next we examined the geometries and stability of SACs adsorption on the C3N3 monolayer (Fig. 2 ). To investigate the feasibility of TM atoms adsorption, we calculated the TM atoms adsorption energies using Eq. (1) and plotted in Fig. 2 s. The results indicate that the adsorption energies of TM atoms on the C3N3 monolayer range from −0.76 to −3.16 eV, suggesting that the central hole site in C3N3 serves as the most favorable anchoring site for SAC adsorption. Each SAC forms bonds with three neighboring carbon atoms, with bond lengths varying from 1.97 Å (Co) to 2.60 Å (In), as shown in Table 1 . The Bader charge analysis shown in Fig. 2 t and Table 1 also revealed that huge amount of charge transfers between C3N3 monolayer and SAC confirming the stability of SAC on C3N3. To further check the stability of SACs on C3N3, we calculated the diffusion barriers of SACs migrating from a hole site to the nearest hole site (Figure S4) using the CI-NEB method. The estimated barriers are: Co (0.60 eV), Ni (0.70 eV), Cu (1.50 eV), Zn (1.15 eV), Ru (0.89 eV), Ag (1.05 eV), Pt (0.80 eV), Au (1.45 eV), and In (2.15 eV). The corresponding final-state energies after migration are slightly lower than those of the initial configuration (−0.05 to −0.32 eV) as shown in Figure S4, indicating that both sites are thermodynamically favorable. Overall, barriers above ∼0.5 eV for most metals suggest limited atomic mobility and strong resistance to aggregation under typical reaction conditions, with Cu, and In exhibiting particularly high kinetic stability. Furthermore, the adsorption of single-atom catalysts (SACs) on C3N3 modulates the electronic structure of the pristine C3N3 monolayer. The projected density of states (PDOS) (Fig. 3 (a-i)) reveal that C3N3 without SAC and with various SACs adsorbed shows metallic characteristics, with band spreading across the Fermi level (EF) and can significantly tune the electronic characteristics of C3N3. Moreover, the charge distribution shown in Fig. 2(a–r) reveals that the high electrical conductivity of the SAC/C₃N₃ monolayers arises from the delocalized electrons at the interface between the C3N3 monolayer and the anchored SACs. The improved CO2RR catalytic performance of SACs/C3N3 was therefore anticipated after modifying the C3N3 with SACs. Adsorption and activation behaviors of CO2 and H2O molecules on surface of SACs supported C3N3 was calculated as shown in Fig. 4 . To Furthermore, to quickly check the most active single atom for CO2 electroreduction to CO and HCOOH, we compared the adsorption behaviors of CO2 and H2O on SACs/C3N3. Different from the conventional viewpoint that H2O is a polar molecule and presents higher chemical activity than CO2 under similar circumstances, therefore, it can obstruct CO2 activation via occupying the active sites of the electrocatalyst. Our calculated results reveal that CO2 adsorbs strongly on the Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt and In surface compare to H2O (Fig. 4 c), whereas H2O adsorbs strongly on the Ag and Au surface compare to CO2, as described in Fig. 4 c. Due to strong interaction between SACs sites of SAC/C3N3 and CO2, the chemical bonds are formed between SACC (∼1.96 Å) and SACO (2.05 Å). Moreover, both the angles O = C in adsorbed CO2 are tilted from 180° to 170.4° and each O = C bond distance enlarges to 1.22 Å compare with the gas-phase value of 1.18 Å. The elongation in CO bonds shows that the adsorbed CO2 is activated by SACs sites in SACs/C3N3. Moreover, CO2 gains charge from SACs as indicated in Fig. 4 d, which is consistent with prior reports [48,49]. On the contrary, due to the relatively lower adsorption energy of H2O on SACs/C3N3 system, the bond distance between OCu is ∼2.14 Å which is longer than Cu-C (∼1.96 Å). Similarly, a small distortion appears in adsorbed H2O molecule with HO-H bond tilting from 103.2° to 106.3° however, change in each HO bond length is negligible, and is elongated from 0.97 Å to 0.98 Å. Moreover, Bader charge analysis, as shown in Fig. 4 d, reveals a minimal charge transfer (0.02–0.11 |e|) between H2O and SAC/C3N3. Thus, we can ensure that SAC sites prefer to adsorb and activate CO2 rather than H2O. From the above analysis, we believe that the Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt and In SACs in SAC/C3N3 exhibit selective adsorption towards CO2 molecules in a moist or aqueous circumstance, which is promising for CO2 electrocatalytic selective conversion. Subsequently, the free energy diagram was employed to investigate the CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR) mechanism on SACs/C3N3. 3.2 CO2 reduction pathways on SACs/ C3N3 The CO2 reduction reaction (CO₂RR) on single-atom catalysts (SACs) supported on C3N3 mainly follows two reaction pathways: one leading to CO through a *COOH intermediate, and the other to HCOOH through an *OCOH intermediate. To evaluate which path is more favorable, the Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) for each step were calculated and are listed in Table S1-S2. At an applied potential of 0 V vs. RHE, CO2 is first activated by a proton–electron transfer on SAC site, forming either *COOH (carbon-bound) or HCOO* (oxygen-bound). These intermediates determine the product selectivity: *COOH leads to *CO, while HCOO* leads to HCOOH [37,50,51]. Further protonation forms *CO or *HCOOH, which then desorb as final products. These steps depend strongly on the type of metal atom used, which influences the overall activity and selectivity of the SACs/C3N3 system. Fig. 5 (a) and (b) show the energy profiles for both pathways across different SACs. In the *COOH route (Fig. 5a), Co (ΔG1 = 0.30 eV, ΔG2 = 0.05 eV), Cu (0.24, 0.09 eV), and Ru (0.38, −0.19 eV), exhibit the lowest energy barriers, indicating their high activity for CO generation. In contrast, In (0.84, −0.15 eV), Zn (−0.38, 0.48 eV), Pt (0.59, 0.06 eV) and Ni (−0.89, 0.10 eV) show significantly less favorable values for CO formation. Fig. 5(b) illustrates the *OCOH pathway toward HCOOH. Here, In (−0.13, 0.11 eV) and Cu (0.34, −0.11 eV) are most efficient, with relatively low energy requirements for both intermediate formation and product desorption, demonstrating high selectivity for formic acid. Co (−0.686, 0.0745 eV), Zn (−0.76, 1.04 eV), and Ni (−0.465, 0.2184 eV) show limited HCOOH activity due to less favorable energetics. Pt (0.8, −0.47 eV) and Ru (−0.85, −0.28 eV) are either inactive or overly bind intermediates, reducing their overall selectivity. The overpotentials (η) associated with CO and HCOOH formation were computed based on the largest thermodynamic energy barrier (ΔG_max) identified from the DFT-derived free energy diagrams, as presented in Table S3. This aligns well with the data summarized in Table 2 , which compares selectivity and efficiency among various metals. Cu emerges as a versatile catalyst capable of promoting both CO and HCOOH production. In is highly selective for HCOOH but underperforms for CO, while Co and Ru demonstrate high CO selectivity but limited activity toward HCOOH. Pt shows strong CO binding yet fails to facilitate intermediate formation, rendering it inactive for HCOOH. The projected density of states (PDOS) plots in Fig. 3 illustrate the electronic interactions between SAC d-orbitals and the C3N3 support. Notably, Cu/C3N3 (Fig. 3 d) exhibits significant d-orbital density near the EF (−2 to +1 eV), with clear hybridization with C-p and N-p states. This indicates strong orbital coupling with both *COOH and *OCHO intermediates, consistent with its dual selectivity toward CO and HCOOH. In contrast, In/C3N3 (Fig. 3 l) shows that In d-states lie deeper below the Fermi level (∼ −2 to −4 eV), with limited participation in electronic states near EF. This weaker coupling favors stabilization of *OCHO over *COOH, supporting selective HCOOH production. These trends underscore the role of d-orbital positioning in product selectivity. Figs. 5 (c, d) illustrate the complete reaction cycles for CO and HCOOH formation, respectively. In Fig. 5 (c), the CO pathway involves the transformation: CO₂ → *COOH → CO → CO(g). In Figure 5(d), the HCOOH pathway proceeds through: CO₂ → HCOO → *HCOOH → HCOOH(g). The asterisks in the diagrams denote key intermediates, and the reactions are shown step-by-step. These visual pathways clearly demonstrate how different SACs facilitate or hinder specific steps, explaining the observed selectivity in Figs. 5 (a, b). To evaluate the selectivity of SACs toward CO2RR over the competing HER pathway, we calculated the Gibbs free energy of H adsorption (∆G_H*) on each SACs supported C3N3 (Fig. 6 ). An ideal HER catalyst should exhibit ∆G_H* ≈ 0 eV, indicating optimal binding of H atoms [14,52]. The schematic of reaction pathways (Fig. 6b) illustrates that SACs such as Co, Cu, Ru, and In exhibit slightly higher ΔG_H* values (0.32–0.45 eV), indicative of suppressed HER activity. These metals also present low overpotentials for CO or HCOOH production (Table S3) and therefore favoring CO2RR. In contrast, Pt and Ni display lower ΔG_H* (0.11 and 0.20 eV), resulting in enhanced HER activity and reduced CO2RR selectivity. This combined analysis provides a strong thermodynamic basis for understanding and predicting CO2RR selectivity over HER in SAC/C3N3 systems. 4 Conclusion This study presents a systematic and in-depth theoretical investigation of single-atom catalysts (SACs) based on transition metals (Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, In, Au, and Ag) anchored on carbon nitride (C3N3) monolayer, using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT). The C3N3 substrate, with its zero bandgap, high electrical conductivity, and symmetric CN lattice, offers a structurally and electronically ideal platform for stabilizing atomically dispersed metal centers an essential requirement for high-performance electrocatalysis. The results reveal that SACs exhibit strong binding energies on the C3N3 monolayer, forming stable single-atom configurations with minimal aggregation tendency. These metal atoms create localized charge redistribution that effectively activates CO2 molecules by weakening the inert C = O bond via electron transfer. A clear product selectivity trend emerges among the studied metals: Cu and In show high affinity for the formation of formic acid (HCOOH) by stabilizing the *HCOOH intermediate while destabilizing *CO, thereby favoring the associative reaction pathway. In contrast, Co, Cu, and Ru preferentially promote CO evolution due to stronger *CO stabilization and weaker interaction with formate species. The synergistic interaction between the conductive C3N3 support and the anchored transition metals enables efficient electron transport, robust atomic stability, and tunable catalytic activity. This atomic level control over product distribution underscores the potential of C3N3-supported SACs as versatile platforms for targeted CO2 electroreduction. Moreover, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) analysis reveals that Co, Cu, Ru, and In exhibit higher H adsorption free energies (ΔG_H*), indicating suppressed HER activity and enhanced CO2RR selectivity compared with Pt and Ni. These insights offer valuable design principles and mechanistic understanding for the rational development of next-generation SACs, paving the way for efficient, selective, and scalable carbon-neutral energy technologies. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) anchored on triazine-based 2D carbon nitride (C3N3) offer a promising pathway for efficient and selective electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. However, a clear understanding of the CO2 reduction process on C3N3-supported SACs is still lacking. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are employed to uncover a comprehensive mechanism and the origin of activity of various transition metal atoms (Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, In, Au, and Ag) on C3N3 monolayer. The importance of the adsorption mode is revealed, as key intermediates exhibit distinct binding configurations that significantly impact catalytic performance. Electron accumulation near the single metal sites activates CO2 via charge redistribution and π-backdonation mechanisms. Thermodynamic and kinetic analyses indicate that Co, Cu, and Ru favor CO formation due to optimal adsorption energies and moderate *CO binding, while Cu and In promote HCOOH production through stabilized *OCHO intermediates. Charge density differences, projected density of states (PDOS), and reaction free energy pathways highlight the role of d-orbital–intermediate coupling and active site characteristics in product selectivity. Additionally, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) analysis reveals that Co, Cu, Ru, and In exhibit higher ΔG_H* values, indicating suppressed HER activity and enhanced CO2RR selectivity compared with Pt and Ni. These insights provide a mechanistic foundation for the rational design of high-performance SACs supported on C3N3 for efficient CO2 conversion.
